title: July 2014 Paper 2 - Licensure Exam
description: NCK Community Health Nurse (Basic) Licensure Examination Paper Two from July 2014. Covers MCQs, Short Answer, and Essay questions converted for interactive practice.

questions.question: The diameter of the pelvic brim that plays a role in determining the outcome of occipito posterior position is:-
questions.explanation: The sacrocotyloid diameter (distance from the promontory to the iliopectineal eminence) is critical in posterior positions. A reduced diameter prevents the head from entering or rotating correctly.
questions.hint: This diameter relates to the sacrum and the side of the pelvis.

questions.question: The hormone responsible for rise in temperature immediately after ovulation is:-
questions.explanation: Progesterone has a thermogenic effect, raising basal body temperature by 0.2-0.5°C after ovulation.
questions.hint: This hormone prepares the body for pregnancy and is high in the luteal phase.

questions.question: The positive signs of pregnancy include:-

options.text: Visualization of fetus by x-ray at 16 weeks, foetal heart sound by Doppler at 5+ weeks.
Visualization of gestational sac by trans-vaginal ultrasound at 4-5 weeks, foetal heart sound by fetal scope at 20 weeks.
Uterine souffle at 12 – 16 weeks, Braxton Hicks at 16 weeks.
Visualization of foetal pulsation by trans-abdominal ultrasound at 5 weeks, foetal heart sound by foetal scope at 16 + weeks.

questions.explanation: Positive signs are undeniable proof of pregnancy: ultrasound visualization, fetal heart sounds, and palpable fetal movements by the examiner.
questions.hint: Look for direct evidence of the fetus itself.

questions.question: Mrs. Y comes for her first antenatal clinic. Her last menstrual period was 25.4.2011. Her expected date of confinement will be:-
questions.explanation: Naegele's Rule: Add 7 days to the day (25+7=2nd of next month), subtract 3 months from month (April-3=Jan, but since we crossed into May, it's Feb), add 1 year. Result: 2.2.2012.
questions.hint: Add 7 days, subtract 3 months, add 1 year.

questions.question: The effects of diabetes mellitus on pregnancy include:-
questions.explanation: UTIs are significantly more common in diabetic pregnancies due to glycosuria. Neuropathy can be a complication. Polycythemia is a fetal effect, not a maternal effect on pregnancy.
questions.hint: Sugar in the urine feeds bacteria.

questions.question: The definite indications for an episiotomy include:-

options.text: Scaring from female genital cutting, fetal distress.

questions.explanation: A rigid perineum that fails to stretch and a preterm baby (to reduce intracranial pressure on the soft skull) are classic indications.
questions.hint: Think about protecting a fragile baby or managing a tissue that won't stretch.

questions.question: Mrs. K. begins to bleed heavily immediately after delivery. In sequence, your actions would be:-

options.text: Call for help, make rapid evaluation, massage uterus, give oxytocin 10 I.U.
Massage uterus, give oxytocin 20 I.U, catheterize, take blood.
Call for help, catheterize, deliver placenta, examine birth canal.
Start I.V. line, deliver placenta, examine birth canal, give ergometrine.

questions.explanation: The PPH sequence is: 1. Call for help, 2. Assess/Massage uterus (stop bleeding), 3. Give oxytocic, 4. IV fluids/Monitor.
questions.hint: Never leave the patient; stop the bleeding first.

questions.question: In 2nd stage, the head delivers but tries to return ('Turtle Sign'). Your immediate action sequence is:-

options.text: McRoberts Manoeuvre, episiotomy, supra-pubic pressure, Rubin’s, Woods.
Reassure, summon help, episiotomy, change position, Rubin’s.
Summon help, reassure, change position, McRoberts, supra-pubic pressure.
Summon help, Rubin’s, supra-pubic pressure, Woods, episiotomy.

questions.explanation: This is Shoulder Dystocia. HELPERR protocol: Help, Episiotomy, Legs (McRoberts), Pressure (Suprapubic), Enter (Rubin/Woods). Option A follows the physical steps best.
questions.hint: Flex the legs first (McRoberts), then push above the pubic bone.

questions.question: Match the items in Column A with Column B:

pairs.right: Contraction lasts longer and is intense at fundus
Ridge between upper and lower uterine segment

questions.explanation: Fundal dominance ensures contractions start and are strongest at the top. The retraction ring (physiological) marks the junction of the active upper and passive lower segments.
questions.hint: One describes muscle action, the other describes anatomy.

questions.question: In breech delivery, the 'hands off' principle is maintained to:-

options.text: Allow enough room for the foetus to pass.
Allow gravitating descent of the foetus.

questions.explanation: 'Hands off' prevents premature traction which can cause the head to extend (deflex) and become trapped.
questions.hint: Pulling too early is dangerous.

questions.question: On abdominal exam, sinciput is felt and occiput just felt. Descent is:-
questions.explanation: Using the rule of fifths: 2/5 means the sinciput is felt but occiput is just/not felt, indicating the head is engaged.
questions.hint: If you can feel 2 fingers width, the head is engaged.

questions.question: Sagittal suture in Left Oblique, occiput points to Right Iliopectineal Eminence. Position is:-
questions.explanation: Right Iliopectineal Eminence is anterior. Occiput pointing there means it is Right and Anterior = ROA.
questions.hint: Locate the occiput: Right side + Anterior landmark = ?

questions.question: Maternal danger signs during labour include:-

options.text: Meconium stained liquor, falling BP, abnormal abdominal contour.
Increasing apprehension, inadequate contraction, abnormal contour.
Pathological retraction ring, falling BP, meconium stained liquor.

questions.explanation: Pathological ring (rupture risk), falling BP (shock), and meconium (distress) are critical signs.
questions.hint: Look for signs of obstruction, shock, and fetal distress together.

questions.question: Prophylactic drugs given to a term newborn at birth are:-

options.text: 3% tetracycline eye ointment, vit. K 0.5mg i.m.
Gentamycin eye drops, vit K. i.m.
1% tetracycline eye ointment, vit K 1 mg i.m.
Gentamycin eye drop, vit. K 1 mg i.m.

questions.explanation: Standard prophylaxis is 1% Tetracycline (eyes) and 1.0mg Vitamin K (IM) for term babies.
questions.hint: Term babies get the full dose of Vitamin K.

questions.question: A 1800g baby with apnea should be nursed in:-
questions.explanation: For an 1800g baby, the neutral thermal environment in an incubator is typically 32-34°C.
questions.hint: Small babies need higher temperatures.

questions.question: Side effects to look for during phototherapy include:-
questions.explanation: Skin rashes (bronze baby), loose stools, and isolation from the mother are key side effects.
questions.hint: Look for skin issues and social effects.

questions.question: Following C-section, wound and lochia should be observed at least:-
questions.explanation: In the immediate post-op period, checks are frequent (every 30 mins) to detect hemorrhage early.
questions.hint: Immediate post-op care requires frequent monitoring.

questions.question: By 9th to 10th day postnatally the uterus is usually palpated:-

options.text: Midway between umbilicus and symphysis pubis.

questions.explanation: By day 10, the uterus has involuted into the true pelvis and is no longer palpable abdominally.
questions.hint: It disappears behind the pubic bone.

questions.question: Indirect maternal deaths are caused by:-

options.text: Malaria, diabetes mellitus, sickle cell disease.

questions.explanation: Indirect causes are pre-existing diseases aggravated by pregnancy (Malaria, Diabetes, Anemia). PPH/Rupture are Direct causes.
questions.hint: Diseases the mother has that get worse with pregnancy.

questions.question: Delivery register is important because it gives information on:-

options.text: Utilizing of maternity services, mode of delivery.

questions.explanation: The register provides comprehensive epidemiological data on outcomes, demographics, and characteristics essential for planning.
questions.hint: It covers the health outcomes of both mother and baby.

questions.question: When illustrating fetal circulation, which structures should be labeled? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Fetal circulation involves the placenta, umbilical vein, three shunts (Ductus Venosus, Foramen Ovale, Ductus Arteriosus), and umbilical arteries.
questions.hint: Focus on the unique shunts and vessels.

questions.question: Which physiological changes occur in the uterus during pregnancy? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The uterus grows (hypertrophy/hyperplasia), softens, increases blood supply, and forms the lower segment. It does not atrophy.
questions.hint: Think about growth and preparation for birth.

questions.question: Arrange the steps for administering SP (Sulphadoxine Pyrimethamine) in order:

items.text: Advise to skip Folic Acid for 14 days

questions.explanation: Check timing -> Check allergy -> Ensure fed -> Watch them swallow -> Advise on Folic acid.
questions.hint: Safety first (allergy), then administration (DOT).

questions.question: What are the roles of a birth companion during labour? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Alert staff if help is needed

questions.explanation: Companions provide support, comfort, and advocacy. They do not perform medical procedures like VEs.
questions.hint: Supportive roles only, not clinical ones.

questions.question: Which interventions are specific for a Trial of Labour? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Trial of labour requires vigilance for obstruction/rupture. Induction is generally contraindicated in trial of labor (e.g., after CS).
questions.hint: Watch closely for failure/rupture and be ready to operate.

questions.question: What are the benefits of Kangaroo Mother Care (KMC) to the mother? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Eliminates need for any hospital stay

questions.explanation: KMC boosts bonding, milk, and confidence. While it reduces hospital stay, it doesn't always eliminate it entirely.
questions.hint: Physical and emotional benefits for the mom.

questions.question: What are clinical features of puerperal psychosis? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Psychosis is severe: hallucinations, delusions, confusion, and rejection of baby. It is distinct from mild 'blues'.
questions.hint: Think 'Loss of Reality'.

questions.question: Select the criteria for Lactational Amenorrhea Method (LAM): (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: The LAM triad: No periods, Exclusive breastfeeding, Baby < 6 months.
questions.hint: The 'Rule of 3' for LAM.

questions.question: Calculate the Perinatal Mortality Rate (per 1000) given: Live Births=1300, Stillbirths=200, Early Neonatal Deaths=200.
questions.explanation:
Formula: (Stillbirths + Early NND) / (Live + Still) * 1000. 
Case A (200 NND): (200+200)/(1300+200)*1000 = 400/1500*1000 = 266.7.
Case B (200 Total Perinatal): 200/1500*1000 = 133.3. Both accepted depending on interpretation.
questions.hint: Add Stillbirths and Neonatal deaths, divide by Total Births, multiply by 1000.

questions.question: What are the aims of Focused Antenatal Care (FANC)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: FANC emphasizes quality over quantity (fewer focused visits), prevention, detection, and planning.
questions.hint: Focus on the 4 pillars of FANC.

questions.question: What information helps develop an Individual Birth Plan? (Select all that apply)

options.text: Place of delivery and skilled attendant

questions.explanation: A birth plan covers logistics: Where? Who? How (money/transport)? What if emergency (blood/decisions)? Baby gender is not a planning logistic.
questions.hint: Think logistics and emergency preparedness.

questions.question: Which blood investigations are routine at first FANC? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Routine profile includes Hb, Group/Rh, VDRL, and HIV. LFTs are only for specific indications.
questions.hint: The 'ANC Profile'.

questions.question: What are the cardinal signs of Respiratory Distress Syndrome (RDS)? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Cardinal signs: Fast breathing, Grunting (keeping air in), and Retractions (working hard to breathe).
questions.hint: Signs that the baby is struggling to breathe.

questions.question: What is included in the management of a baby with RDS? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Support breathing (O2), keep warm (incubator), maintain sugar/hydration (IV), and treat infection. Bathing is contraindicated.
questions.hint: Supportive care: Air, Warmth, Fluids, Drugs.

questions.question: How can Respiratory Distress Syndrome be prevented? (Select all that apply)
questions.explanation: Preventing prematurity, using steroids to mature lungs, managing diabetes, and avoiding asphyxia reduce RDS risk. Early elective CS increases risk.
questions.hint: Mature the lungs before birth.
